text.Prompt:
Lubomira Rochet said that investment in digital channels, which accounted for 30% of L'Oréal's total media spend in the first half of 2016, was due to rise this year. Over the same period in 2015, the share was 25%.

She told Campaign that L'Oréal is adopting a strategy that acknowledges the range of ways that consumers are influenced. This includes through celebrities, online influencers and "micro-influencers" – people in their peer groups.

L'Oréal bolstered its operations in the second of these groups by picking Scandi-navian social influencer platform Tailify as one of the first five start-ups in its accelerator programme run with Founders Factory. The beauty giant is now working alongside Tailify to find influencers to col-laborate with across 70 markets.

Rochet said L'Oréal's marketing across every platform started from "a common trend where you want to have this conversation and advice with people that look like you".

Another of the tech start-ups chosen by L'Oréal two weeks ago, Veleza, is an app-based beauty community that supports the peer-to-peer influencer ecosystem by connecting people who share similar tastes and skin types.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: L'Oreal has increased its share of investment in digital channels by 5% over the last year. They are adopting a multi-pronged approach to marketing that acknowledges the range of ways consumers are influenced, including celebrities, online influencers, and "micro-influencers" in their peer groups. They have partnered with a Scandinavian social influencer platform to find influencers to collaborate with across 70 markets, and also partnered with an app-based beauty community that connects people based on shared tastes and skin types.
text.Response B: Hmm, it looks like the L'Oréal marketing team is planning to increase their spending on digital channels in 2016.  They are focusing on developing campaigns that use online influencers and micro-influencers, who are people in their peer groups that influence consumer behavior.  L'Oréal thinks that these types of influencers are very important, and they are working with a startup company called Tailify to find online influencers to work with in 70 different countries.  They are also working with another startup called Veleza, which is an app-based beauty community that connects people with similar tastes and skin types.  Overall, it sounds like L'Oréal is placing a high priority on digital marketing channels and is actively working with technology startups to develop innovative campaigns.

meta.preamble_a: Respond authoritatively, assertively and persuasively, as if you are very knowledgeable about the topic.
meta.preamble_b: Respond in a cautious, defensive and uncertain way, as if you are unfamilar with the topic.

599.displayed_text:
Prompt

Lubomira Rochet said that investment in digital channels, which accounted for 30% of L'Oréal's total media spend in the first half of 2016, was due to rise this year. Over the same period in 2015, the share was 25%.

She told Campaign that L'Oréal is adopting a strategy that acknowledges the range of ways that consumers are influenced. This includes through celebrities, online influencers and "micro-influencers" – people in their peer groups.

L'Oréal bolstered its operations in the second of these groups by picking Scandi-navian social influencer platform Tailify as one of the first five start-ups in its accelerator programme run with Founders Factory. The beauty giant is now working alongside Tailify to find influencers to col-laborate with across 70 markets.

Rochet said L'Oréal's marketing across every platform started from "a common trend where you want to have this conversation and advice with people that look like you".

Another of the tech start-ups chosen by L'Oréal two weeks ago, Veleza, is an app-based beauty community that supports the peer-to-peer influencer ecosystem by connecting people who share similar tastes and skin types.

Generate a summary:

Response A

L'Oreal has increased its share of investment in digital channels by 5% over the last year. They are adopting a multi-pronged approach to marketing that acknowledges the range of ways consumers are influenced, including celebrities, online influencers, and "micro-influencers" in their peer groups. They have partnered with a Scandinavian social influencer platform to find influencers to collaborate with across 70 markets, and also partnered with an app-based beauty community that connects people based on shared tastes and skin types.

Response B

Hmm, it looks like the L'Oréal marketing team is planning to increase their spending on digital channels in 2016. They are focusing on developing campaigns that use online influencers and micro-influencers, who are people in their peer groups that influence consumer behavior. L'Oréal thinks that these types of influencers are very important, and they are working with a startup company called Tailify to find online influencers to work with in 70 different countries. They are also working with another startup called Veleza, which is an app-based beauty community that connects people with similar tastes and skin types. Overall, it sounds like L'Oréal is placing a high priority on digital marketing channels and is actively working with technology startups to develop innovative campaigns.
